A few shots were fired by the accused at the police personnel before they were nabbed, said the DGP, adding that entire operation was handled delicately so that the maryada and sanctum sanctorum of the Gurdwara Sahib was not disturbed in any manner.

“The accused included the five persons involved in the brutal attack on the Punjab Police team posted at the vegetable market in Sanaur early on Sunday morning. They had crashed through a series of barricades and attacked the police personnel who inquired about their curfew passes, said the DGP Gupta, adding that Baba Balwinder Singh, the Nihang Head, was the main perpetrator of the attack on the police party at the Patiala Sabzi Mandi this morning. He came to the market with four other persons, in a Tata Xenon vehicle.

DGP said a huge cache of weapons as well as hand-held weapons, such as barchhe and kirpans, and some used cartridges were seized from the accused, in addition to two petrol bombs and LPG cylinders, five bags of poppy husk mixed with sulpha, other drugs in commercial quantity and Rs 39 lakhs in cash. Some bottles with chemical substances were also found inside the premises.

ASI Harjit Singh, whose hand was reportedly cut off with a sword during the attack at the vegetable mandi, has undergone a plastic surgery at PGI Chandigarh for suturing back his hand, where he was rushed after the incident, said the DGP.

Besides, Sadar Patiala SHO Inspector Bikkar Singh also suffered sharp weapon injuries on his left arm, leg and back, ASI Raj Singh was inflicted a sharp weapon injury on his left leg, and ASI Raghbir Singh had got blunt injuries on his body. In addition, a Mandi Board official AR Yadwinder Singh also suffered some minor injuries in this attack.

Title: Wheat procurement amid Covid-19 scare in Punjab
Article:
Amidst coronavirus scare, Punjab is all set for procurement of nearly 137 metric tonnes of wheat through 3,691 purchase centres across the State, besides ensuring strict implementation of health protocol and social distancing.

The State Government, on the directives of the Chief Minister Capt Amarinder Singh, has made elaborate preparations to ensure smooth and hassle free procurement of wheat during Rabi Marketing Season-2020-21 amid trying circumstances due to Covid-19.

Taking stock of arrangements to ensure that every single grain of farmers produce would be procured at all costs, the Additional Chief Secretary (Development) Viswajeet Khanna said that all requisite arrangements are in place by the Mandi Board well in advance for the procurement which will begin from April 15 and continue till May 31 and if need be, till June 15.

Divulging the preparedness plan for wheat procurement during the current RMS, Khanna said that the Cash Credit Limit of Rs 22,900 crore has already been approved by the Centre to ensure prompt and seamless procurement operations in the State.

He said that foolproof arrangements have been made in wake of coronavirus to ensure wheat procurement in all 22 districts by creating a vast infrastructure of 3691 purchase centres including 153 main yards, 280 sub-yards, 1434 purchase centres besides adding 1824 yards of rice mills, especially during this season.

He also mentioned that nearly 137 lakh MT of wheat is expected to arrive in the mandis, of which 135 lakh MT would be purchased by Government agencies while two lakh MT is likely to be bought by private traders. The Centre has fixed the minimum support price (MSP) of wheat at Rs 1,925 per quintal for the current RMS against Rs 1840 MSP fixed last year, he said.

Nearly 182 lakh MT of total produce is expected and 17,500 combine harvesters would be operating for harvesting the wheat crop in the State.

Against the total requirement of 4.82 lakh gunny bales, 3.05 lakh have already been made available. Likewise, the arrangements for 47,000 tarpaulins against total demand of 52,570 and 29,261 mesh nets against 32,805 have already been made. Similarly, required wooden crates for storing the bagged wheat are also being arranged in time.

Khanna said that amendment of Agricultural Produce Market Committees (APMC) Act has been notified to make payment electronically to farmers through arhtiyas (commission agents) within 48-hour after the lifting of produce.

To avoid crowding, maintain safe social distance norms and ensure smooth

procurement, Khanna said that a detailed action plan has been chalked out to undertake procurement by staggering arrival of produce in mandis by issuing coupons fixed with holograms to the farmers through arhtiyas. With each coupon, a farmer will be entitled to bring one trolley of about 50 to 70 quintals of wheat.

A farmer shall be entitled to take multiple coupons each day or in different days depending on space in the purchase centre in order to avoid rush in mandis. About 27 lakh such coupons would be issued by market committees to arhtiyas.

Emphasizing the need to strictly observe necessary safety and sanitary protocols to curb the spread of coronavirus, observance of social distancing norms, wearing of masks and use of sanitizers will be ensured.

Mandi yards are being marked with 30×30 feet lines to accommodate a heap of about 50 quintals and maintain sufficient distance from the adjoining one.

District level Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) have been issued to the Deputy Commissioners and SSPs to ensure strict compliance of these protocols. Harvesting operations by combines have been allowed between 6 am to 7 pm, added Khanna.

Provision for clean drinking water, fumigation, cleaning and disinfection of mandis and mandi yards is being ensured.

Over one lakh masks and 25,000 litres of sanitizer have been received for use in each of these purchase centres.

“Under the District Level SOP, the DCs would be overall in-charge of procurement operations to oversee activities including issuing and distribution of coupons from April 12 (Sunday) onwards, availability of mandi labour in all 3691 centres,” he said.

Apart from these, the DCs have also been mandated to review storage point labour for unloading, mandi wise transport arrangements, maintaining cleanliness and sanitation of mandis, storage point, arhtiya shops besides lifting of sold wheat within 48 hours, revealed Khanna.

Notably, a 30-member control room has been set up in the Mandi Board head office and in each of the designated purchase agencies to meticulously coordinate procurement operations and logistics with each district 24X7.

Title: Stop installing disinfection tunnels: Health Dept
Article:
Concerned over increasing instances of installation of disinfection tunnels in different places, the Uttarakhand government has said that such equipment serves no purpose and their installation should be discouraged. The decision of government came after the World Health Organisation (WHO) expressed concern over the installation of disinfectant tunnels in markets and other places and said that these tunnels are actually defeating the purpose for which they are being used.

WHO said that these tunnels create a false sense of security and feared that the people may get diverted from hand wash to disinfection tunnels. “The spraying of alcohol, chlorine or Lysol on human beings is not only harmful but also ineffective. These tunnels should not be installed and used,’’ a circular of WHO said.

In an order to all district magistrates (DM) and chief medical officers (CMO), the additional secretary medical health, Yugal Kishore Pants said that the installation of disinfectant tunnels are not according to the advisory issued by the government of India.

Title: Anganwadi workers to receive no pay for strike period: Kamthan
Article:
The State Government will not pay any remuneration for the two months during which Anganwadi workers were on strike. No allowance was promised to the workers for these months after they ended their protest, said the director of Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS) Jharna Kamthan.

Recently, the State president of Anganwadi workers association Rekha Negi said that the State Government deducted their two months allowance despite the promise made by Dehradun mayor Sunil Uniyal 'Gama' as the Government's representative before the suspension of their two months long protest.

Negi said, "It is quite insensitive of the Government to take such action. Hundreds of Anganwadi workers are widows, single mothers, and abandoned women, and deducting their allowance during the lockdown in the State is wrong and cannot be justified by the state administration."

However, ICDS director Jharna Kamthan does not agree that the Government promised no deduction in the remuneration of two months. "It is a false claim by the Anganwadi workers that the Government promised to pay allowance for their protest period of two months," said Kamthan. According to her, the Anganwadi workers receive honorarium for their job so there will be deductions for their absence from the work too. "It has always been this way with the Anganwadi workers. Even few years back, they staged a protest for few a weeks and during that time the allowance was deducted too," added Kamthan.

On the other hand, Negi stated that if the government will maintain such an “autocratic” attitude towards the Anganwadi workers, they will not work amid the situation caused by COVID-19 pandemic.

"I hope the government will pay our allowances soon or we will be bound to stop supporting government during the current crisis," added Negi. However, Kamthan had stated earlier that the Anganwadi workers cannot refuse working during the coronavirus crisis.

Title: Prepare work plan for encouraging bee-culture in mountains: CM
Article:
A work plan should be made for facilitating improvement in the financial condition of people in mountainous regions through bee-culture. Chief Minister Trivendra Singh Rawat said this after about 20 kilogrammes of honey was produced in one month from a bee box in the Chief Minister’s residence.

The CM said that clusters should be made in each district to encourage bee-culture. In the rural areas, bee-culture along with agriculture will be effective in further improving the financial condition of farmers. Small groups of farmers should be formed and bee-boxes should be made available to them, said Rawat. He also sought information about honey productivity in Dehradun from the chief horticulture officer Meenakshi Joshi, while adding that focus should also be laid on production of raw honey. The Minister of State for Higher Edu, Dhan Singh Rawat, labour and contract advisory board chairman Shamsher Singh Satyal and the CM residence horticulture in-charge Deepak Purohit among others were present on the occasion.

Title: PRSI invites entries from children for online art competition
Article:
Having made efforts to raise public awareness and provide ration kids for the needy, the Public Relations Society of India (PRSI) Dehradun chapter is now organising an online drawing competition to encourage the creativity of children amidst the lockdown to contain the spread of COVID-19.

The chapter chairman Amit Pokhriyal, secretary Anil Sati and treasurer Suresh Bhatt informed that the chapter has been raising public awareness through mass media on social distancing and other information for protection from COVID -19. The PRSI Dehradun chapter is now organising an online drawing and painting competition on the theme 'India United against Corona'. Children in the 7-14 years age group can participate and sent their entries either on WhatsApp or via e-mail.

Ten best drawings will be selected by the team formed by PRSI Dehradun chapter. First three children will be given special prizes with certificate of appreciation.

Rest seven will be given consolation prizes with certificates. All the winners of the online competition will be informed telephonically and will be felicitated when the conditions normalise.

Details of the competition are available on www.prsidehradun.com.

The competition is free and the last date for submission is April 25.

Title: Faith leaders discuss measures for tackling Covid-19
Article:
The Global Interfaith WASH Alliance organised a webinar in partnership with UNICEF Tanzania on "Proactive Faith Leadership in the Time of Crisis" with interfaith leaders of Africa and India. This was the second in GIWA's series of interfaith webinars on the topic of the novel Coronavirus crisis.

The panel brought together eminent Christian leaders of Africa. The religious personalities discussed uniting together as faith communities to conquer the challenges faced by the world today. All the panelists encouraged people to stay at home, keep social distancing and take all safety precautions possible to stay safe and well.

Swami Chidanand Saraswati, co-founder and chair of the Global Interfaith WASH Alliance and president of Parmarth Niketan in Rishikesh said, “Faith Leaders, you are agents of change. We need to come together and urge governments to take the lead in helping communities address COVID-19. We can fight the spread of the novel coronavirus in our countries.” He also led a special prayer with the panelists at the end for all those afflicted by the virus so that they may heal, for all of the frontline workers and healthcare providers as well as for all of humanity.

Sadhvi Bhagawati Saraswati, secretary general of GIWA and president of Divine Shakti Foundation, moderated the panel and emphasised the crucial messaging that faith leaders must be sending out to their followers, such as the critical importance of hand-washing, social distancing and staying at home. She shared the experiences already felt by all in India and the steps the government is taking towards ensuring the safety of the nation, as well as how Parmarth Niketan is offering a full daily and weekly online schedule to uplift all those at home across the world.

Archbishop Thabo Makgoba, South African Anglican Archbishop of Cape Town and Trustee of GIWA, said, “Let's support the government to flatten the curve. We are not disobeying god by staying home. Instead, this decision is sacred, biblical and critical to protect one another.”

Frederick Shoo, presiding bishop of the Evangelical Lutheran Church in Tanzania said, “As we celebrate Easter, we have advised people in the risk groups to stay home during this time. We are encouraging people to keep their faith in god. Faith is important right now as it helps to maintain the calm.”

Reverend Charles Kitima, secretary-general of the Tanzania Episcopal Conference, shared, “We are using YouTube and radio to reach our worshippers and are encouraging them to stay connected even in their homes. Our key messages for all Tanzanians are to frequently wash their hands and practice social distancing at this time.”

James Elder, Chief of Communications, Eastern and Southern Africa for UNICEF urged everyone, “Kids are a part of the solution. Listen to them, especially now.

They can help to spread key messages. Support their learning at home but also allow children to have ‘corona-free’ time. It is important for them to still feel like children during this time.”

Title: No help from dist admin reaching us: Councillor
Article:
The councillor of Reethamandi, Itaat Khan, alleged that the people in his area are not getting any kind of help from the district administration, especially in the Muslim colony which was sealed after COVID-19 positive patients were found there. However, the district administration has denied the allegations, stating that essential items are being provided in the area.

The Dehradun district administration is claiming to provide all the essential items to the locals in the sealed areas of the city. Zakir Ansari, son of the sealed Bhagat Singh Colony councillor Illiyas Ansari informed that the police and district administration are providing all the essential items to the locals and destitute people in his ward.

"Ration, milk and even mobile ATMs are being provided by the administration for the locals of the ward. Though the garbage is not being picked up yet in this area, but sanitisation of the whole area is done regularly by municipal corporation of Dehradun, " said Ansari.

However, according to Itaat Khan , he has not received any help from the district administration regarding the ration being made available to the locals. "There are no means of buying ration or other necessary items like milk or tea for thousands of people in this area. The administration has not provided anything here for the last many days.

The destitute and daily wagers are bearing the brunt of this colony being sealed as they do not even have money to buy the ration," said Khan. "Even our MLA Vinod Chamoli and Dehradun mayor Sunil Uniyal 'Gama' did not contact me to know the condition of the locals. The police are doing the best they can, we have no issues with them," added Khan.

He said that he had talked to Dehradun DM Ashish Kumar Srivastava who assured him that all the necessary services will be provided in the said area but nothing has been done so far by the district administration.

Regarding allegations leveled by Khan, Dehradun Chief Development Officer (CDO) Nikita Khandelwal said that only Bhagat Singh Colony where maximum COVID-19 positive patients were found is completely sealed including the grocery stores.

The people of other areas can buy the necessary grocery items from the internal shops of their colony as they are not entirely sealed.

According to her, the district administration is providing ration and other essential items to the grocery stores in Muslim Colony so that locals can get the items from there.

Title: State reports second Covid-19 death
Article:
Jharkhand reported its second death due to coronavirus with total number of positive cases in the State going up to 17, health officials said. The second death was reported at the trauma centre of Rajendra Institute of Medical Science (RIMS), Ranchi, on Sunday. RIMS director Dr DK Singh confirmed the death of patient. The deceased is husband of a corona infected woman, a resident of Hindpiri locality of Ranchi.

According to health officials, the deceased (60) had no travel history and was detected corona positive few days back and was admitted at RIMS. Sources said that the patient was suffering from breathing problem and was put on ventilator.

Dr Vijay Bihari, Ranchi’s civil surgeon, told media persons that the man was among the eight people brought to RIMS from Hindpiri area of the state capital. Sources said that deceased got the infection from his wife, who was infected by a Malaysian woman.

Jharkhand had registered its first confirmed case on March 31, when a 22-year-old Malaysian woman tested positive for the virus. She was the part of a 22-people group, including 17 foreign nationals, who were recovered from two mosques in Ranchi. The group had come to Ranchi last month after attending Tablighi Jamaat congregation in New Delhi.

Earlier, a 72-year-old man from Gomia’s Sadam village in Bokaro district had died of coronavirus on April 9. Meanwhile, as the reports of death of man spread, there was panic in Hindpiri locality as people from same area after the detection of first coronavirus case had not cooperated with district administration team who had gone for testing.

The residents had protested against district administration and health team claiming that in name of test they are carrying of NRC, NPR survey.

Meanwhile, residents of Ratu Road and Bariatu area staged a protest after news spread that the deceased will be buried at Ratu Road Kabrishtan. The residents from nearby Mohallahs staged a protest against district administration decision to bury the body at Ratu Road Kabrishtan, later the administration changed its decision. Ranchi SDM, Lokesh Mishra said, “Due to public protest the body will not be buried at Ratu Road Kabrishtan, the district administration team is finding other place where the body will be buried.”

Meanwhile apart from death of a patient at Hindpiri area, no new positive cases were reported on Sunday. Out of the samples collected, Number of positive cases is 17. By Sunday, the total samples collected is 2117 out of 1666 samples have been found to be negative. Out of the samples collected, Number of test in progress is 434. Number of person in home quarantine is 1,08,911 at 15,548 quarantine centres.

Title: Collectors must be on toes to end crisis: CM
Article:
Chief Minister Shivraj Singh Chouhan has said that all the Collectors should work with full vigilance to end the Corona crisis from the State as quickly as possible.

To prevent infection, the boundaries of the districts should be sealed and movement in hotspot areas should be completely closed. Supply of medicines, milk, vegetables, fruits, groceries etc. to the public should be ensured through district administration.

The Chief Minister was reviewing the situation and arrangements of Corona in all the districts of the state through video conferencing today. All the concerned senior officials including Chief Secretary Shri Iqbal Singh Bains, Additional Chief Secretary Health Mohammad Suleman and Director Public Relations OP Shrivastava were present.

The Chief Minister directed that the number of Corona Testing Labs should be increased. Currently 7 labs are working. For this, testing should be started in all medical colleges. Ensure testing facility in private medical colleges too.

Additional Chief Secretary Mohammad Suleman said that 22 districts of the state have been affected by Corona. One Corona infected patient has been found in the newly infected districts of Ratlam and 1 in Mandsaur.

One positive case each of Corona has been found in Ratlam and Mandsaur districts. Both have already been placed in quarantine.

The Chief Minister directed the collectors to seal the infected areas immediately, complete contract tracing and take all necessary steps so that the infection does not spread.

The Chief Minister directed the collectors to ensure continuous supply of medicines, milk, fruits, vegetables and groceries in the state. He told them to seek cooperation of voluntary organizations and public representatives in this work. Fruits and vegetables should be purchased from the farmers after decentralizing big mandis and administration should make proper arrangement in this regard.

The Chief Minister said that the team of Indore is working day and night, but I am more worried due to maximum number of cases there.

The administration should ensure the best treatment there, hot spots should be strictly sealed and intensive health testing should be done. ACS Health directed that oxygen should be available on every bed for treatment.

Title: PCC chief meets CM, appreciates Govt efforts
Article:
With the cooperation of all, widespread awareness and strong will power, the State can face the situation resulting from the COVID-19 pandemic. CM Trivendra Singh Rawat said this while interacting with Pradesh Congress Committee president Pritam Singh and few other Congress leaders who visited the CM residence on Sunday.

The PCC president discussed various public issues and appreciated the efforts being undertaken by the State government for protection from the spread of COVID-19, while assuring full support to the State Government for this.

Rawat said that effective efforts are being undertaken so that the general public does not face problems during the lockdown in force to contain the spread of the virus. Necessary facilities will also be provided to farmers for harvesting in addition to ensuring social distancing and provision of masks for this purpose. The distribution of masks made by self help groups is also being facilitated in the state.

The CM further said that there is adequate arrangement for food grains and other essential commodities have been made in the state. Necessary facilities are being provided to those kept in quarantine, tourists stranded in the state due to the lockdown and others, added the CM. Congress leaders including Lalchand Sharma, Ajay Singh and ex-MLA Rajkumar were also among those present during the discussion.

Title: 4 more test corona positive, total cases 54 in State
Article:
Fresh COVID-19 cases continued to be reported in the State with four more persons testing positive for the deadly disease late on Saturday night.

This takes the total number of coronavirus cases to 54 barely some hours after National Health Mission (NHM) Director Shalini Pandit gave some relaxing news.

The Health and Family Welfare Department in its official twitter post confirmed that four persons Saturday tested positive to the highly infectious virus. Of these four cases, two are from Bisra town in Sundargarh district while one case each was reported from Rajnagar in Kendrapada district and Bhubaneswar.

The two cases from Sundargarh district are that of two males and have a Nizamuddin Markaz link. Both were on quarantine in the Rourkela COVID-19 Hospital.

The district administration and police officials on Sunday morning sealed Bisra town. Entry points at Dareikela, Puruna Bisra, Budheljar and Santoshpur were blocked to restrict movement of people in and out of the area. Fire Services personnel were engaged to disinfect the area.

A meeting between the district Collector and SP was held to take a decision regarding imposition of shutdown in Bisra town.

The woman patient of Rajnagar in Kendrapada district has a travel history to West Bengal. On March 29, she returned with her father and another person from Kolkata. Later, she and her father were in home quarantine.

Meanwhile, she has been shifted to the Ashwini Hospital in Cuttack and her father, mother and brother are in home quarantine. The swab samples of the family members were collected and sent for testing. Two villages in the area have been declared as containment zones and a disinfection drive was carried out. A door-to door screening of the nearly 150 households of the area was also carried out, said Kendrapada Collector Samarth Verma on Sunday.

Notably, this is the second COVID-19 case in the district. Earlier, a 32-year-old man of the district, who had returned from Dubai, tested positive for the virus.

With the four new case s, the number of COVID-19-affected persons in the State has increased to 54. The number of active cases stood at 41 as 12 persons were cured and discharged from hospitals while an elderly man has died of the coronavirus.

Of the total 3,551 samples tested so far, 3,497 tested negative while 54 samples gave positive result to the COVID-19.

Title: Study to asses mental health of doctors, frontline warriors
Article:
In view of the increasing complaints of anxiety, depression and gloominess among the people due to the threat created by the novel Coronavirus (COVID-19), the Government Doon Medical College (GDMC) has designated a senior faculty member to counsel such patients on phone. The Principal of the GDMC, Dr Ashutosh Sayana said that the college has asked the head of department (HoD) of Anatomy, Dr M K Pant to remain available on phone or whatsApp to counsel the patients of depression and anxiety. Dr Pant would be available from 5 pm to 6 pm on phone number 9917979743. Dr Pant said that it is essential to remain mentally strong in the prevailing circumstance where the COVID-19 infection is spreading. He said in all the patients of the disease who have recovered from the infection, maintaining mental strength played a key role in their victory over the disease.

Dr Pant who incidentally is also an expert in psychiatry said that he has started a research on all healthy doctors and other staff members engaged in battle against COVID-19. In the research, the effect of the scare of disease on mental health is being studied.

“All frontline Covid-19 warriors are needed to be mentally strong. The research would help in formulating a policy to tackle the disease,’’ he said.

Title: Himgiri Zee University conducts online classes
Article:
Amidst the lockdown to contain the spread of COVID-19, Himgiri Zee University has been conducting online classes for its students.

On March 24, class group on Whatsapp and group email were activated. Students were intimated that classes will be held on daily basis with the pre-published time table. Students were advised to create Zoom, Skype ID for class interaction.

The university has been conducting regular online classes for its students through different platforms.

The university also thanked the Tata Consultancy Services for offering its online platform (TCS ION) free of cost to all Indian institutions and many departments have shifted to TCS ION for academic delivery.

The university vice chancellor professor Rakesh Ranjan assured students that the university will ensure that their studies are not hampered. While all the theoretical classes will be completed online, practical classes will be conducted once the students report to campus after normalisation of the situation.

Title: Normal deaths fall drastically in Sambalpur
Article:
A cartoon portraying the mythological character of Yamraj (death god) has now gone viral in the social media in which the god is appealing to people not to come in more numbers to him since his place (Yamapur) is ‘houseful’.

And that seems to be true in Sambalpur with the number of general deaths falling drastically during the ongoing coronavirus-related lockdown.

“There are also days when there is not even a single death,” said Kandarpa Rakhas, the in-charge of Rajghat, the main crematorium for Sambalpur city and suburbs. “I and the other staffs are astonished. But we are happy,” said Rakhas.

“Normally, an average of six dead bodies comes for cremation every day. But it has been reduced drastically in the recent days. And the reason is not known,” said Subhransu Nayak, the overall in-charge of Rajghat. “But we are happy that we don’t have to witness more such scenes like before,” Nayak said, adding that only 11 bodies were cremated during the last seven days.

The municipality authorities also admitted the fact.

Title: Police book case against fraud offering online liquor sale
Article:
Cyber frauds are exploiting the situation resulting from the lockdown by attempting to defraud those looking to buy alcohol and other items.

During the ongoing lockdown to contain the spread of novel coronavirus (COVID-19) only the shops selling essential commodities are open while other shops including liquor shops and bars are closed. Taking advantage of this situation, some cyber criminals are spreading advertisements on the social media claiming to provide home delivery of liquor and other items in an attempt to con the public.

On Sunday, Karnpur resident Indravir Saral lodged a complaint in the cyber crime police station that an unidentified person had made a page on Facebook and displaying the name and address of Saral’s departmental store, was advertising online sale of liquor. This fraud was conning the public through the mobile phone on the pretext of selling liquor. The police have lodged a case under section 420 of IPC and section 66 C of the IT Act.

Deputy inspector general (STF) Ridhim Aggarwal has requested the public to not get taken in by such advertisements regarding online sale of items. She also warned that strict action will be taken against any person who makes a fake ID and puts up fake news on the social media or any person who forwards such fake news without verifying it first. Citizens are requested to inform the cyber crime police station at 1035-2655900 or mail at ccps.deh@uttarakhandpolice.uk.gov.in in case they come across anyone spreading such fake advertisements on the social media.

Title: Daylight armed robbery reported at petrol pump in Jhabreda; 50K looted
Article:
Bike borne criminals robbed Rs 50,000 at gunpoint from a petrol pump in the Jhabreda area of Roorkee on Sunday. On receiving information about this daylight robbery, the Haridwar senior superintendent of police Senthil Avoodai Krishnaraj S and other police officers reached the site.

According to official information, three men on a motorcycle reached the Vikrant and Kartik filling station in Khajuri village on Sunday afternoon. Petrol pump owner Vikrant Tyagi said that the miscreants looted about Rs 50,000 from the salesman at gunpoint.

Police swung into action and apart from putting up blockades on routes, also began checking footage from the CCTV cameras at the petrol pump and nearby locations in an attempt to identify the culprits. The SP (Rural) Swapan Kishore Singh said that teams have been formed and are working to crack the case.

Title: Financial aid continues for corona-affected: CM
Article:
The process of financial support continues for the welfare of Corona affected people from different districts of the state following Chief Minister Shivraj Singh Chouhans appeal.

While on the one hand senior litterateurs of the capital Bhopal pledged to contribute to the Chief Minister’s Relief Fund, other social organizations have also extended their helping hand in times of this calamity on the other hand.

Every citizen of the state is playing the role of a warrior in this war. This awareness will give a distinct identity to the state.

On Chief Minister Chouhan's call, several industrial organizations have extended financial support for assistance in the fund. Assistance is also being provided in the Chief Minister’s Relief Fund from Hindi Bhavan.

Chief of Hindi Bhavan Trust, Shri Kailash Chandra Pant, said that in just 5 days of the call of Chouhan, an amount of Rs one lakh has been deposited by litterateurs. Youth of NCC and NSS are engaged in generating public awareness work in various districts of the State.

People are being told to fully follow the lock down. Just as Sushma Kelkar, an elderly woman in Indore, has taken the initiative to make masks on her own, in the same way, Jyoti Jain of Jabalpur has prepared about 5000 masks and distributed them in different areas. Not only this, they were also sanitized and made aware of the method of its use.

The order to provide food to the police personnel doing duty during lockdown by citizens is also going on. In Tulsi Nagar, Shivaji Nagar areas of Bhopal city, women provided food packets to policemen.

Awareness increasing

Every person should use mask, for this, there are reports of mutual advice being given by citizens, which is an example of public awareness of the State. The news of Corona infected coming back home from the hospital in large numbers also excited the public.

While on the one hand, Chief Minister Chouhan is getting information about medical efforts and support of people during a high level review meeting every day, on the other hand, this sentiment is visible in villages in every district.

Not only senior administrative officials but also functionaries of social organizations have presented examples of working as Corona warriors. Because of this, the work of controlling Corona virus in Madhya Pradesh is getting continuous success.

Madhya Pradesh will become an example for other States

The Public representatives are also active to ensure that Madhya Pradesh should become an example for other States.

The Chief Minister Chouhan in the first week itself after taking the charge of the state inspected the arrangements at women hostels, control room, food and quarantine arrangement himself and boosted the morale of the team. Other elected public representatives are also constantly working to control Corona.

Former Minister Narottam Mishra made people aware of the importance of maintaining cleanliness and distance in Datia.

Shri Shailendra Jain is making people aware of the importance of sanitizer in Sagar. News of such initiatives by the public representatives in Indore, Hoshangabad, Khandwa, Alirajpur, Mandla and Sidhi districts are also coming.

In Gwalior and Chambal area, the common people have also become aware of the Corona infection and are combating corona infection. This spirit of co-operation with the Government will soon succeed in controlling the corona virus in the State.

Today, various voluntary organisations informed about the work being done to tackle Corona. This include workers of Jan Abhiyan Parishad, Gayatri Parivar and volunteers of Seva Bharti.

These efforts will not only make the efforts of Madhya Pradesh Chief Minister Chouhan day and nights hard work meaningful, but will also write a new history of public participation in the important work of disease control and saving lives of the citizens.

Title: inmates to be shifted at Old Jail to curb virus spread
Article:
To check dissemination of Coronavirus infection taking precautionary measure around 3,000 jail inmates of Bhopal Central Jail and staff, jail authorities have decided to shift new inmates at Old Jail, in Arera Hills area; the move would maintain social distancing among the jail inmates.

At the time of pandemic which has never been witnessed no any case could be ignored as there is no history of the ways of spreading of infection and due to which the decision was taken after a miscreant serving jail from Indore to Jabalpur jail, tested positive for Coronavirus.

Title: Police book three miscreants for attacking 35-year-old man
Article:
Kolar police have booked three miscreants for attacking a 35-year-old man with wooden sticks after he opposed cattle of accused destroying his crops at Gol villages on Saturday.

According to the police, the victim, Mukesh Lodhi, was attacked by miscreant Dinu and his two friends with wooden sticks and the injured victim was rushed to a nearby hospital where he was reportedly stable. In the initial investigation, it was found that Mukesh own farms at Gol village while cattle owned by Dinu entered the farms and damaged the crops and when he opposed the accused Dinu and two others attacked him and later escaped the spot.

The victim lodged a complaint with Kolar Nagar police and based on the complaint and after the preliminary investigation, the police have registered a case under section 294 , 323 and 506 of the IPC and have started further investigation.

The miscreants are yet to be arrested. The victim sustained injuries in his hands, shoulder and head. He tried to save but failed and was beaten brutally. Crime record of the miscreants would be investigated. The accused and the victim are residents of same village.

The victim used to vigil the crop which was scheduled to be yielded but as the lockdown was imposed he failed to yield the crop. In the afternoon he was guarding his field when Mukesh came with cattle which entered the farms.

The family and friends of the accused would be questioned to determine the whereabouts of the absconding accused.

Title: Massive sanitation drives in corona-hit zones launched
Article:
With spike in corona positive cases in Delhi, Chief Minister Arvind Kejriwal on Sunday announced the launch of massive sanitisation drives in ‘red’ and ‘orange’ zone to contain the virus spread under the Operation - SHIELD.

The massive drive will start from Monday and to make it possible at larger scale keeping escalating corona patients in mind, the five has joined hand with a Japanese industry named - PI.

Incidentally, announcing it, Kejriwal said that the PI has provided hi-tech machines covering 20 Thousand Square meter area in one hour to us free of cost. “We are in collaboration with PI industries and Delhi Jal Board ( DJB); while DJB will do sprinkling with 50 small machines, the PI machines will help in covering large volume in less time,” Kejriwal added.

Importantly, Kejriwal government is escalating sealing wherever Coronapatients are being reported by health authorities.

For this, the government has divided areas in two main zone- Red and Orange.

“Areas which have been declared as containment are the Red zone while where the high risk zones are - Orange,” “Our government termed High Risk Zone to few areas with the consultation of health experts panel,” Kejriwal added.

“Massive sanitization drive being started all over Delhi. We are making every effort to ensure you stay safe,” Kejriwal said while interacting digitally with media.

Further, after the success of Operations Shield in Dilshad Garden, Delhi government has planed to implement it in more defined areas.

Meanwhile, Kejriwal and Transport Minister Kailash Gehlot also announced the transfer of Rs 5000 in the account of Public Sector Unit Transport drivers with a condition to have valid driving license.

He said, "We have procured 10 high-tech Japanese machines for sanitization from PI industries. One machine can sanitize 20,000 sq/m in one hour. Along with this, 50 small machines will be procured from the DJB. From tomorrow, a massive sanitization program will be carried out in red and orange zones in Delhi."

"We are doing whatever we can to ensure that you stay safe. We are learning, observing and implementing all the measures taken in other nations. We are also taking all measures for the security of the most vulnerable and poorest sections of society. We are providing food for these people. Around 71 lakh beneficiaries are provided ration and 23 lakh beneficiaries, who do not have ration cards, have applied and they will also be provided ration through our schools. Apart from drivers, the construction workers have also been provided Rs. 5000 as relief assistance', the chief minister added..

Title: Wearing mask made compulsory in G’gram
Article:
The Gurugram district administration has made it compulsory for residents of the district to wear face masks while stepping out of their house.

Violating the instruction may attract legal action under section 188 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC). If anyone without wearing masks on roads or any other public places.

“Wearing masks is compulsory even while travelling in personal or government vehicles. The violators will be booked under Section of 188 (Disobedience to order duly promulgated by a public servant) of the Indian Penal Code (IPC),” read the orders.

As per the guidelines issued on Thursday, the 3 km area from the houses of corona infected persons will be declared as containment zones.

The SDM of the areas will decide the area of containment zones. They will be assisted by area ACP and SHO of Gurugram police.

"It is applicable for every citizen, government officials and any other employees associated with essential services. It is also applicable to motorists too while driving private or government vehicles. Also, government officials should also wear face masks on the ground. They will be not allowed in meetings if they would not wear proper face masks," said Amit Khatri, the district magistrate of Gurugram.

It is pertinent to mention that several states have made it mandatory for people to wear masks in a bid to contain the spread of coronavirus.

Gurgaon is among the worst-affected districts in the state with 32 COVID-19 cases besides Nuh with 38 cases, Palwal with 28 and Faridabad with 28 cases.

In the Gurugram district out of 32 positive cases, 12 corona infected patients have been discharged now and 20 are admitted in different hospitals.

As a preventive measure, the district administration has already declared 9 areas as containment zones in the wake of the fast-spreading coronavirus.

The nine areas include Sector-9, Sector-54/Nirvana Country, Palam Vihar, Emar Palm Gardens Sector-83, Laburnum Society, and Sector-39. Besides, three villages namely Fazilpur Jharsa, Ward Number 11 Pataudi and Village Raipur Sohna where corona infected patients are found.

Title: Keshopur Mandi directed to enforce social distancing
Article:
The Delhi Police on Sunday said the suppliers and buyers at Keshopur Mandi, one of the largest fruit and vegetables market in West Delhi, have been strictly directed to maintian social distancing and function as per time restriction to contain the spread of coronavirus.

According to police, the traders are allowed to function from 5 am to 12 noon and local buyers are allowed to visit mandi from 12 pm to 7 pm only.

“Commercial vehicle are not allowed to be parked after a validated period. To ensure strict adherence of directions, two Inspectors with one platoon of local police and one company of outside force have been deployed on daily basis” said Deepak Purohit, the Deputy Commissioner of Police (DCP), west district.

“The strong pickets have been erected to restrict entry of unauthorised persons on the road facing the mandi. Vendors have been made to arrange fruit and vegetables at proper distance. Authorities have been requested to remove stray animals from Mandi. It has been decided to close Mandi for two days for the purpose of sanitisation,” said the DCP, adding that the police teams will also do verification of vendors and buyers before entry.

“Proper marking signs have been made to ensure social distancing while banners and posters have been placed at locations to create awareness about the directed instruction in the wake of corinavirus pandemic. Public Announcement System is being used to reiterate instructions to the visitors at the mandi. The police have also deployed volunteers to ensure observance of regulations. Besides, 20 Civil Defence personnel have been also been deployed to ensure all directives are followed,” said the DCP adding that no vehicle is allowed to enter without valid entry pass and action will be taken against violators.

The police are also using drone surveillance in other wholesale vegatable markets, including Azadpur and Gazipur, to ensure all directives are being followed.

In south Delhi, the Mehrauli Sabzi Mandi has been shifted to bus terminal in order to ensure social distancing.

According to Atul Kumar Thakur, the DCP, South district markings have been done and meeting was held with Pradhan to ensure social distancing and sanitisation.

Title: ‘Flu corners' at Charak Palika Hospital to screen Covid-19 patients
Article:
In the wake of coronavirus outbreak, New Delhi Municipal Council (NDMC) has opened a unique 24×7 flu corner at the Charak Palika Hospital (CPH) to check patients complaining of fever and other related symptoms.

The flu center has been developed by the NDMC at Moti Bagh in New Delhi. It has a glass barrier to avoid human touch between Health Care Provider ( HCP ) and patient.

A senior NDMC official said that this flu corner will ensure protection to the healthcare providers (doctors and other medical staff) besides saving personal protective equipment (PPE) used to check coronavirus affected person.

“The design involves a temporary structure made of canvas with a glass partition. The glass partition with microphone facility provides effective protection at the time of patient interaction with the healthcare provider,” he said.

The official further said that the flu corner is constructed in an open area, away from the main Charak Palika Hospital within its premises. “A CCTV camera is installed at the flu corner which is connected with the Central Control and Command Centre (CCC) under the smart city mission,” he added.

Title: 3,462 detained for violating lockdown guidelines in City
Article:
The Delhi Police on Sunday registered over 250 cases and detained 3,462 people across the national Capital for violating Government orders during the coronavirus lockdown.

According to the data shared by the police, 278 cases were registered under section 188 (for disobedience to order duly promulgated by public servant) of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) till 5pm.

Police said that a total of 3,462 people have been detained under section 65 (persons bound to comply with reasonable directions of police officers) and 479 vehicles have been impounded under section 66 of the Delhi Police Act.

“The police also registered 121 cases against people for stepping outside their residence without wearing masks. A total of 432 movement passes have been issued,” police said.

Since March 24, over 75,000 people have been detained so far for violating order under section 65 of the Delhi Police Act.

However, On Sunday Delhi Police received over 700 calls on their 24x7 helpline number to resolve issues related to lockdown. Police said that total 18,220 number of calls received by police till Sunday on their helpline 011-23469526.

“Police received 771 calls from Saturday 2 pm to Sunday 2 pm. Out of 828, around 60 calls were related to outside Delhi, which have been referred to respective state helpline numbers. A total of 25 calls were received related to no food/no money, which have been forwarded to NGO for direct relief at their addresses,” said police.

“While four calls were received regarding medical issues and have been resolved through proper guidance to proceed in case of such emergencies while 555 calls were related to movement passes and were advised to apply online on website of Delhi Police,” said police.

The move comes following nationwide restrictions due to complete lockdown imposed across the country to contain Coronavirus.

Title: ‘Sanitising Trunk’ useful compartment for police working as frontline force
Article:
Brain child of IIT Ropad and adopted by Karnal police ‘Sanitising Trunk’ is a useful compartment for police personnel working as frontline force and require their belongings on the field to be ‘senitised’ and taking cue from the concept 7th Battalion Bhopal has made these special box to protect uniform material from corona infection Boxes. The 7th Corps Special Armed Forces of Bhopal has made special boxes with the technology to protect the uniform material of its frontline personnel from corona infection. The boxes are based on the technology of Ultraviolet Sanitization Box prepared by IIT Ropar.

The 7th Corps has also started using the Ultraviolet sanitiser box. Through these boxes, uniform material such as belts, caps, batches, etc. of personnel specially posted on duty and other armed forces officers are being protected from infection

. Taking cue from Karnal police in preparation of special UV sanitiser box which is low cost and easily made 7th Battlion Bhopal has prepared these boxes which are very useful at the time of the Coronavirus infection spread as the complete uniform of a police personnel requires protection.

The use of the box is simple as it has to be switched on for 20 minutes by keeping all items from outside like uniform, belts, currency notes,

food items, wallets, mobile phones and other documents and later after 20 minutes it has to be left for 10 minutes after which the items could be used.

The normal trunk at the police stations could be used for the purpose and around Rs 500 is required to prepare the trunk.

Title: On CM order, dept calls for use of Assembly funds for Covid-19 protection
Article:
On the instructions of the Chief Minister Shivraj Singh Chouhan, the Planning, Economics and Statistics department has issued an order that the amount of Assembly Constituency Area Development Plan can be used for protection from Coronavirus pandemic and its prevention.

On the recommendation of the MLAs, Collectors will be able to use the amount of this plan in various Corona prevention works.The Department of Planning, Economic Statistics has asked all District Collectors to use this amount in buying infrared thermometers, PPE kits, Corona testing kits, ventilators, isolation/quarantine ward construction, masks, gloves, sanitisers or other health equipments recommended by the Ministry of Health.

The criteria to determine material will be in accordance with the Public Health and Family Welfare Department. The purchasing activity will be carried out with full transparency as per the procedure prescribed by the department.

The Chief Medical and Health Officer will maintain record of material. It is essential to do audit work under rules of State Government.

Title: NTA notice to candidates for corrections on centre choice
Article:
The candidates appearing for JEE Main can now make changes in their applications till April 14. The National Testing Agency (NTA) issued an official notice that the candidates can make corrections in the choice of their centres.

The candidates can choose the nearby city as the exam centre. According to the notice, due to COVID-19, the candidates can make changes in their online application.

It is to be noted that the examinations of Joint Entrance Examination (JEE) Mains have been postponed. The examinations were scheduled to be held on April 5, 7, 9 and 11.The students are really worried about the examinations. Due to lockdown in the country, the city students are unable to go for coaching and group studies. Hence, the students are preparing at home for the examinations.According to a notice issued on the official website of JEE Mains, the April examination has been postponed.

The notice states that in pursuance of MHRD letter, the competent authority of the National Testing Agency has postponed the ensuing JEE (Main) April 2020 examinations scheduled on the April 5, 7, 9 and 11.Through the notice, the students are also informed about the admit cards. The candidates and their parents are advised to keep visiting jeemain.nta.nic.in and www.nta.ac.in for latest updates.

They are also being informed individually through their registered mobile number and email-id. The candidates can also contact at 0120 an official phone number for any further clarification provided on the website. “The candidates are requested to undertake the correction(s) very carefully as no further chance of correction will be provided to the candidates,” the circular reads.

Title: MPSD shuts classes, says will resume once situation gets normal
Article:
Due to the outbreak of coronavirus, the Madhya Pradesh School of Drama (MPSD) has shutdown the classes. As the nationwide lockdown is announced, the students of the current batch are informed that the classes will resume after the situation gets better.

It is to be noted that the entire campus of MPSD was also sanitized due to the serious outbreak of Coronavirus. Looking into the safety of the students, the decision has been taken. It is to be noted that earlier all the workshops and guest lectures have been cancelled till March 31. The students of batch 2019 have returned to their home towns. But, now the date is extended and after the lockdown the classes will resume. Besides, students from all over the country applied for the current batch of MPSD.

This decision is taken by the Madhya Pradesh School of Drama, in view of public health and public interest in the State, to protect against the infection of the Corona (Covid-19) virus caused by the disease in public places, sports grounds / campuses together in groups common citizens. As a result of the gathering, precaution has been taken to prevent the possible risk of Corona (Covid-19) virus infection.

In this regard, Director of MPSD Alok Chhatterjee gave instructions to the students to be safe. He also gave message to wash hands regularly and avoid social meetings.

Title: 65-yr-old woman, 7-yr-old boy test +ve in Ujjain; total at 18
Article:
With two more persons testing positive for Coronavirus the total number of patients has raised to 18 in the district; a 65-year-old woman and a 7-year-old boy are the two who have been tested positive.

The two patients detected on Sunday are family members of the woman who died of Coronavirus infection few days ago who was resident of Ramprasad Bhargava Marg.

After the reporting of two cases Kot Mohalla and Ramprasad Bhargava Marg has been declared as cantonment area.

The death toll remained at 5 in the district till Sunday while three family members of woman were discharged on Saturday who were undergoing treatment and their test report came negative on Saturday. The three were undergoing treatment at R D Gardi Medical College. The family of Bhargava Marg had already done Quarantine, those who came in contact would also be investigated. The health department got little respite as no case was reported within last three days but after receiving the Corona positive report of the mother and son of Bhargava Marg late night people are panicked.

CMHO Dr. Mahavir Khandelwal said that after the death of a woman resident of Bhargava Marg, her samples were taken and the dead woman was found to be corona positive.

After this, the samples were taken by quarantining her family. Her report has been received and the 65-year-old woman and her 7-year-old son, who are among the kin of the deceased, have also turned out to be Corona positive.

However, both had already been quarantined and are undergoing treatment.

Title: Police book two youths for sedating 2 minor boys
Article:
The Kamla Nagar police have booked two youth who sedated two minor boys in the name of providing medicine for Covid-19 and provided them sleeping pills at Mandwa basti area; boys went unconscious after taking pills and are reportedly stable.

In-charge of Kamla Nagar police station, Vijay Singh Sisodiya said that the accused Ritik and Lucky who lured the two victims that they have medicine for Coronavirus infection and provided them sleeping pills.

The accused are real brothers and lives in the same area where the victims in the age group of 12 years live. The incident took place on Saturday around 5pm, when the victims were playing outside their home the two accused arrived and lured them by of Coronavirus infection medicines and instead gave them sleeping pills and when the victims consumed the pills they went unconscious as soon as the two went unconscious the accused escaped the spot.

The locals after spotting the two informed the police and a Dial 100 FRV rushed to the spot and reached the spot and were rushed to JP hospital in an ambulance from where they were discharged after primary treatment and their condition is reportedly stable.

Based on the report given by doctors, police in their initial investigation found that they were given sleeping pills. The pills would have been fatal in given in excess but the dosage was not high and which saved the two.

Title: Board examinations: CBSE releases list of few FAQs on website
Article:
The Central Board of Secondary Education (CBSE) has released a list of few Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs) on its official website. The list was released on Saturday wherein FAQs related to board examinations.

Students appearing in the CBSE Class 10 and Class 12 board examinations 2020 can check the updated FAQs related to promotion of students to the next class,

not holding of remaining board examinations in centers located outside India and many such other queries of students on the CBSE website at cbse.nic.in.Most of the FAQs were based on the schools run by CBSE abroad. The questions were posted by the students, of which the answers were given by CBSE. An FAQ talks about board’s decision not to conduct any more examinations for class 10 and class 12 students in schools abroad and what will happen to the results of the class 12 students.

Another FAQ is posted by a student of class 11, wherein he is worried that all his friends were promoted based on their previous performances, but he was detained due to poor academic record. It is to be noted that with the rise of Coronavirus cases in country, all the board exams of class 10 and 12 have been postponed.

Title: 8 people who gathered at Gurdwara defying lockdown arrested
Article:
The Delhi Police has apprehended eight people and registered a case against them for gathering at a Gurudwara in North Delhi’s Kotwali during a lockdown on early Sunday morning.

According to a senior police official, on wee hours of Sunday at 2.15 am, during patrolling Sub-Inspector along with police team checked Gurudwara Sisganj and found ‘paath’ being performed in the Gurudwara, they said.

“On seeing police, the people assembled there started to flee away but the police managed to apprehended eight of them. The apprehended people were served notices under section 41 A Code of Criminal Procedure (CrPC) for violation,” the senior police official said.

“A case was registered against them under section 188 (disobedience to order duly promulgated by public servant), 269 (negligent act likely to spread infection of disease) and 270 (Malignant act likely to spread infection of disease dangerous to life) of the Indian Penal Code at Kotwali police station,” he said.

“The apprehended people were not wearing masks and violated the order of not gathering at a religious place during the Coronavirus pandemic,” the senior police official added.

Title: Maha Govt books 156 Tablighi foreigners for violating visa rules
Article:
The Maharashtra Government has booked 156 foreigners from 18 countries for allegedly violating the visa rules and attending the Tablighi Jamaat event at Nizamuddin in Delhi last month.

Announcing this, State Home Minister Anil Deshmukh said here on Sunday: “The police have booked 156 foreigners for visa rules violations under section 14-B of Foreigners Act, other relevant sections of IPC Further investigations are on”.

The section 14 (b) of the Foreigners Act, 1946 (Penalty for contravention of provisions of the Act, etc) read thus: “Whoever-- does any act in violation of the conditions of the valid visa issued to him for his entry and stay in India or any part thereunder;

Deshmukh said that all these foreigners had been granted a tourist visa for India “but they flouted the norms by visiting the Tablighi Jamaat markaz in Delhi last month”.

The 18 countries from which they came are: Indonesia 37, Kyrgyzstan 19, Myanmar 18, Bangladesh 13, Tanzania 11, Philippines 10, Kazakhstan and Ivory Coast 9 each, Malaysia 8, Togo 6, Djibouti 5, Brunei 4, Russia 2, USA, Benin, Iran, Ghana and South Africa 1 each.

The Minister said that as many as 15 offences have been registered by police in Mumbai, Thane, Navi Mumbai, Amravati, Nanded, Nagpur, Pune, Ahmednagar, Chandrapur and Gadchiroli, and all the foreigners are currently kept in institutional quarantine, he added.

The Maharashtra Government’s stern action against 156 foreign nationals should be seen in the context of its earlier decision to cancel a two-day Tablighi Jamaat event held along the lines of the one held at Nizamuddin which became hotbed for Coronavirus cases.

Title: 1075 +ve cases in TN, death toll reaches 11
Article:
As the number of persons in the State tested positive for coronavirus reached 1075 by Sunday evening, Government of Tamil Nadu has launched an aggressive testing and containment programme to restrict the disease in stage-2 itself, according to Beela Rajesh, Secretary, health and family welfare department.

With 106 persons tested positive for coronavirus on Sunday, the Government increased the number of laboratories in the State where the virus could be tested. “From Sunday onwards, testing could be done in 14 Government laboratories and nine private laboratories. The Central Government owned JIPMER medical college and hospital at Puducherry too would serve as a center for testing samples from Tamil Nadu,” said Beela Rajesh , herself a medical doctor by training.

Out of the 106 persons testing positive on Sunday, 90 are from the single source event held at Delhi and 16 are those who associated with them. The spurt in the number of patients getting admitted to hospitals with coronavirus case has forced the Government to take some more drastic measures. On Sunday two more persons succumbed to the dreaded virus taking the death toll in the State to 11.

The Government on Sunday warned volunteers, NGOs and political parties distributing cooked foods to the homeless and needy in violation of section 144. A Government order in this regard asked the concerned persons to donate the money they spent to Chief Minister’s Relief Fund or hand over the food to Chennai Corporation authorities for distribution among the needy.

The disinfectant tunnels which created a sensation all over the State will no longer be allowed anywhere in Tamil Nadu. The Department of Health by a special Government order asked the officials not to install disinfectant tunnels citing a world health organisation directive which stated that such tunnels would create a false sense of security and people may be diverted from handwash to disinfection tunnel.

Title: Guj: Cases spring up in new areas
Article:
Twenty five more positive cases were detected in Gujarat on Sunday morning and one person has died due to Covid-19, the health authorities announced, taking the total detected positive coronavirus cases to 493 in the state.

Till Sunday, 23 deaths due to coronavirus have been reported in Gujarat.

Despite the health authorities claims of containing the coronavirus spread crammed into limited pockets or hotspots, the virus spread is springing up in new areas in Ahmedabad as well as in other parts of Gujarat.

On Sunday, 25 more positive cases were detected by the health authorities, out of which Ahmedabad had 23. Two cases were from Anand. Many cases were found from areas which have not been marked as hotspots in Ahmedabad like Behrampura, Ghodasar, Ranip, Maninagar. Earlier too, cases were found from Juhapura, New Vadaj, Dudheshwar, Manek chowk in Ahmedabad.

One death was also reported on Sunday, an Ahmedabad male (75) from Ghodasar, admitted in the Ahmedabad's LG hospital, succumbed to the virus late Saturday night. He had comorbidity conditions like hypertension.

With the new addition, Gujarat has now total 493 positive cases of Coronavirus and 23 deaths. Ahmedabad has the maximum number of positive cases (266), followed by Vadodara (95), Surat (28), Bhavnagar (23), Rajkot (18), Gandhinagar (15), Patan (14), Bharuch (8), Anand (7), Kutch (4), Porbandar and Chhota Udaipur (3 each), Mehsana and Gir-Somnath (2 each) and Panchmahal, Jamnagar, Morbi, Sabarkantha and Dahod (1 each).

"Out of the total cases, the condition of 422 is stable while 4 are on ventilator, their condition being critical. A total of 44 patients have been discharged from the hospital after getting treated," said Jayanti Ravi, the principal secretary, Health and family welfare Department, Gujarat.

"Due to the aggressive testing in hotspot areas, under the cluster containment strategy carried out on a campaign mode, we have almost covered all the hotspots. Now the process is stabilized and we are focusing now on the other areas of the city as well as state," added Ravi.

"So far, 687 samples have arrived from areas like Navsari, Valsad, Junagadh, Banaskantha, Amreli, Narmada, Tapi, Jamnagar and Surendranagar. But we have obtained only results of 52, all of which are negative. This is just preliminary figure, within a day or two the picture will be clear," added Ravi.

"In the last 24 hours, we have taken 2,663 samples for the testing, where 61 have been found positive, 2,486 negative and 116 are pending," added Ravi.

The total number of test carried out by the health department till now is 10,994 out of which 493 are positive, 10,397 negative and 407 are pending.

"The total number of quarantined in the state is 15,561, where 14,013 are home quarantined, 1,406 in government facilities and 142 in private facilities," added Ravi.

For clarifications/queries, please contact IANS NEWS DESK at +91-120-4822400 Mobile: +91-9873188969 or mail us at support@ians.in

Title: J&K: Doctor, jawan test +ve, total cases rise to 245
Article:
A lady doctor and a soldier on leave tested positive for Covid-19 along with 19 others in Jammu & Kashmir, taking the total tally to 245 cases on Sunday.

According to official sources, a lady doctor from Jammu, posted in Udhampur tested positive along with one soldier, hailing from Supwal area of Samba,and two others from Jammu while 17 fresh cases were detected from Kashmir region on Sunday. Moving swiftly, all the fresh cases were isolated in dedicated covid hospitals in Jammu and Srinagar and their close relatives were quarantined and their samples were sent for testing.

The authorities on ground zero have tightened the grip especially in red-zones by completely sealing the areas and blocking entry and exit points by spreading concertina wires on different routes.

According to the daily Media Bulletin on novel coronavirus (Covid-19), out of 245 positive cases, 235 are Active Positive, 06 have recovered and 04 have died.

Furthermore, till date 51320 travellers and persons in contact with suspected cases have been put under surveillance which include 9153 persons in home quarantine including facilities operated by Government, 433 in Hospital Quarantine, 235 in hospital isolation and 29718 under home surveillance. Besides, 11777 persons have completed their 28-day surveillance period.

The Bulletin further said that 3355 samples have tested as negative till April 12, 2020.

Providing district-wise breakup, the Bulletin said that Srinagar has 58 positive cases wherein 56 are Active Positive, 01 recovered and 01 has died, Bandipora 42 positive cases with 39 Active Positive, 02 recovered and 01 died, Baramulla 37 positive cases with 36 Active Positive, no case has recovered and 01 died, Budgam 11 positive cases all of whom are Active Positive, Pulwama 03 positive cases-all Active Positive, Shopian and Kupwara with 14 and 23 positive cases respectively and all are Active Positive, and Ganderbal and Kulgam with 05 and 04 positive cases respectively all of whom are Active Positive.

Similarly, Jammu has 21 positive cases of whom 19 are Active Positive and 02 have recovered, Udhampur 19 positive cases of which 18 are Active Positive, 0 recovered and 01 died, while as Rajouri and Samba have 03 and 04 positive cases respectively and all are Active Positive and the single positive case has recovered fully in Kishtwar district.

Title: Farmers should be given relief from lockdown to harvest crop: UP CM
Article:
Farmers should be given relief from the lockdown to harvest crop, and the Uttar Pradesh Government would encourage institutions and agencies to purchase food grains directly from the growers at minimum support price (MSP) or higher, Chief Minister Yogi Adityanath said on Sunday.

He directed officials to start online classes for students of higher education, technical education, nursing and paramedical studies, so that their academic schedule is not wholly disrupted.

Online counselling of students was also discussed at a meeting of officials chaired by Chief Minister Yogi Adityanath. Teachers should be trained for this. On the instruction of Adityanath, the work of providing e-content has been started in all universities. Chhatrapati Shahu Ji Maharaj University in Kanpur has implemented e-education smoothly according to this order.

"At the meeting, the chief minister said since harvesting season is on, farmers should be allowed to move. Apart from Government purchasing centres, if other institutions and agencies want to buy crops directly from farmers, they would be encouraged to do so provided the price is on par with the MSP or above," Additional Chief Secretary (Home) Awanish Awasthi told reporters here.

About arrangements made for the Tablighi Jamaat congregation members traced in the state, he said, "Provisions to quarantine people related to the Tablighi Jamaat have been made so as to stop further spread of Covid-19.

Title: Opp flays Centre for suspending MPLAD
Article:
But over 5K cr MPLADS funds remain unused

The Opposition has criticised the Centre for suspending the Member of Parliament Local Area Development (MPLAD) scheme for two years, but an analysis of the scheme reveals that over the years the trend of Parliamentarians failing to use the fund optimally for their constituencies has been continuing.

As on March 4, 2020, the Ministry of Statistics & Programme Implementation data shows the unspent amount to be Rs 5,275.24 crore.

In fact, the data shows that the unspent money under the MPLAD Scheme rose by a whopping 214.63 per cent between the 15th and the 16th Lok Sabha. And when compared with the 14th Lok Sabha, this rise is even greater — 885.47 per cent.

When taken Statewise collectively, Uttar Pradesh has an unspent amount of Rs 354.58 crore out of the total Rs 14,440 crore released between 2014 and 2019 while Assam has left only Rs 53 crore of the total amount of Rs 257 crore released.

Maharashtra has Rs 185 crore unspent from the total of Rs 774 crore released and Andhra Pradesh has an unspent amount of Rs 80 crore of the total amount of Rs 375crore released. If Karnataka has unspent fund of Rs 106.71 cr out of Rs 452 cr released, then Punjab has unspent amount of Rs 63.54 cr of the total amount of Rs 260 cr released.

Delhi has an unspent amount of Rs 41.38 crore of the total Rs 80 cr released while Madhya

Pradesh has Rs 112.68 cr. Kerala and Gujarat have Rs 72.38 cr and Rs 88.78 cr of unspent funds.

Prime Minister Narendra Modi, who represents Varanasi constituency, has Rs 2.67crore unspent fund out of the Rs 15 crore released under this head while the data shows former Congress president Rahul Gandhi, who represented Amethi, having Rs 4.58 crore unspent out of Rs 12.50 crore released under the MPLADS between 2014 and 2019.

Similarly, Congress interim president Sonia Gandhi has also an unspent amount of Rs 4.64 crore out of the Rs 17.50 crore released during the same period.

The Centre, however, has defended the unspent funds. It recently informed the Parliament that unspent balance is not an unused fund as it also includes the funds in pipeline for implementation of ongoing works.

Nevertheless, unspent funds have been in thousands of crores this last few years. Unspent amount under the scheme was Rs 4,103.97 crore on March 31, 2019; Rs 4,877.71 crore on March 31, 2018 and Rs 5,029.31 crore on March 31, 2017.

And as for the year 2020-21, an allocation of Rs 1,518 cr had already been made before the Centre suspended the scheme to keep its finances for the fight against Covid-19. Of this, an amount of Rs 1,432 cr was left unspent.

Prime Minister Modi has suspended the MPLADS fund for two years 2020-21 and 2021-22 to use a fund of Rs 7,880 crore thus saved to manage the challenges and adverse impact on the economy due to the spread of coronavirus outbreak.

There are 543 MPs in Lok Sabha and 245 MPs in the Rajya Sabha, which means 788 Parliamentarians in all. Each MP gets Rs 5 crore per annum as MPLAD and for two years, which works out to be nearly Rs 7,880 crores.

As per the latest information available with the Parliament secretariat, a total of 355 MPs of 779 MPs (of the total 788) have contributed a total of Rs 365 crore from their MPLADS towards tackling exigencies in India emerging from the effect of the pandemic.

Earlier this week, Rajya Sabha Chairman M Venkaiah Naidu and Lok Sabha Speaker Om Birla had asked MPs to contribute Rs 1 crore from their MPLADS to the PM CARES Fund. They had also asked MPs to contribute a month’s salary to the PM CARES Fund.

Congress president Sonia Gandhi had offered her entire MPLADS fund for the welfare of the people of Rae Bareli in fighting the coronavirus outbreak as per the requirement of the constituency. Congress leader Rahul Gandhi allocated Rs 2.66 crore from his MPLADS money to fight coronavirus in his constituency.

Balashowry, YSR Congress MP from Machlipatnam, has contributed the highest of Rs 4 crore of his MPLAD fund to the Andhra CM Relief Fund while Samajwadi Party leader Mulayam Singh Yadav has donated Rs 25 lakh of his MPLAD fund for purchasing sanitisers and masks in Mainpuri.

Title: With 22 more deaths, toll at 149 in Maha
Article:
In yet another biggest spike in the number of deaths and infections in a day, as many as 22 persons on Sunday succumbed to Covid-19 in Maharashtra taking the total number of deaths to 149 and 221 others tested positive for the pandemic in the State.

On a day when the total number of infected cases in the State rose from 1761 to 1982, Mumbai recorded 16 deaths, while there were three deaths in Pune, two in Navi Mumbai and one in Solapur.

Mumbai, which is the most coronavirus-affected city in the country, has so far recorded 92 deaths and 1298 infected cases.

Of the 22 persons died to Covid on Sunday, 13 were men and 9 women. Six of those dead were aged over 60 years, while 15 deceased were from the age group 40 to 60 years and one was below 40 years “Twenty out of these 22 patients (91%) had high-risk co-morbidities such as diabetes, hypertension, asthma and heart disease,” a medical bulletin released by the State Health Department said.

Out of 41,109 laboratory samples, 37,964 were negative and 1982 have been tested positive for coronavirus until today. As many as 217 patients have been discharged till date after full recovery,” the bulletin said.

“As many as 1,247 people are in home quarantine, while 5064 people are in institutional quarantine,” the bulletin said.

Meanwhile, the state health authorities said that they were carrying out a thorough search of citizens who had attended the religious gathering at Banglewali Masjid at Nizamuddin last month was underway at the level of all districts and municipal corporations.

Of the Tablighi Jamaat event attendees, 755 have been tested and 37 have been found to be positive for Covid-19.

Out of these 37, 8 are in Latur, 7 in Yavatmal, 6 in Buldhana, 3 in Mumbai, and 2 each in Pune, Pimpri-Chinchwad and Ahmednagar, and one each in Ratnagiri, Nagpur Municipal Corporation, Hingoli, Jalgaon, Osmanabad, Kolhapur and Washim. Additionally, 6 contacts of these cases have been found positive in Ahmednagar and 1 in Pimpri-Chinchwad.

The health authorities said that as per the guidance from Government of India, cluster containment action plan was being implemented in places where clusters of patients have been found in the state.

“There are total 4846 surveillance squads deployed across the state and surveillance of 17.46lakh population has been done. Twenty six persons the same family and their contacts had been found positive at Ismalpur in Sangli district. Twenty four of them have been discharged upon recovery until now.

Thirty one surveillance squads regularly searched through the population of over 7,500 in the affected area in Islampur during the last two weeks,” the bulletin added.

Title: Delhi Govt files plaint against fake ration site
Article:
The Food, supplies and consumer affairs department of Delhi Government has written a letter to Special Commissioner of Police, Crime Branch to lodging an First Information Report (FIR) against a ‘fake website’ indulged in cheating people in the name of issuing Ration Card.

According to the letter issued on April 11, an official communication was received from the office of Delhi’s Minister for Food and Supply along with two screen shots and one link stating that a fake website (https://rationcardagent.co.in/digital-ration-card-application/ ) has been created by miscreants for registering digital ration card and asking for Rs 407.

“As per Section 2 (16) of National Food Security Act 2013 Ration Card “means a document issued under an order or authority of the State Government for the purchase of essential commodities from the fair price shops under the targeted public distribution system”.

As mentioned above only government and government alone are competent to issue ration card and there is no enabling provision under law to authorise any agent to issue ration card,” stated the letter.

“It is not only a case of cheating the common man but also amounts to fraudulently and dishonestly cheating him with an intention to have wrongful gains. Besides, it is also a fraud on government. Further, the department is undertaking relief to the people in midst of Covid 19 Lockdown period and poor and needy are being provided ration free of cost,” it further reads.
